texts.text: Back in 2008, I remember sitting in my office on Ren√©-L√©vesque Boulevard, watching the TSX plummet while fielding panicked calls from clients‚Äîone even asked if they should cash out and buy gold bars; I spent hours that week rebalancing portfolios and explaining why panic-selling was the worst move.

Trying to help my daughter pay for her Concordia tuition while keeping up with the mortgage in Rosemont meant I had to swap my usual Laurentian ski weekends for budget-friendly snowshoeing at Mount Royal‚Äîparenting on a middle income in Montreal is a real balancing act.

I still remember the smell of toner and the sound of dot matrix printers in our old office near Place Ville Marie‚Äînow, I review quarterly reports on my tablet during my STM commute, a far cry from the stacks of paper we used to lug around.

Switching between English and French during client meetings in our downtown Montreal office has become second nature, but I still chuckle when I accidentally say 'revenu net' instead of 'net income' during English presentations.

After my divorce, keeping the duplex in Villeray meant cutting back on my annual trip to the Rockies, but I figured having a stable home for my teenage son was worth trading in powder days for budget spreadsheets.

When OSFI rolled out the new capital requirements in the early 2000s, I remember scrambling to update our compliance protocols‚Äîfunny how those changes now feel like ancient history compared to today's fintech landscape.
Walking through the Man the Producer pavilion at Expo 67 with my dad sparked my fascination with economics‚Äîwho knew that a 7-year-old from NDG would end up managing portfolios decades later?
Back in my Dawson College days, I thought my TI-83 was the pinnacle of technology‚Äîuntil it froze during my final exam in Financial Accounting, and I had to finish the amortization schedule by hand.

After a summer internship on Bay Street where I fetched more coffee than I analyzed stocks, I decided to bring my talents back to Montreal, where I could actually manage client accounts before turning 30.
In 2000, I had to explain to a client why their Nortel-heavy portfolio had tanked‚Äîhard to forget the look on their face when I showed them the charts during our meeting at the Peel Street office.
During the Ice Storm of '98, our office in Ville-Marie lost power for three days, and I had to process payroll manually by candlelight‚Äîtalk about old-school finance.
Every February, I max out my RRSP contributions while reminding clients not to forget their TFSA room‚Äîit's become as routine as shoveling the driveway after a Montreal snowstorm.
Mentoring interns from both McGill and UQAM has taught me that explaining EBITDA in two languages is a skill they don't teach you in college.
I still believe in saving for a rainy day, but these days that means diversifying into ETFs and crypto‚Äînot just stuffing loonies into a Canada Savings Bond.
I've been using Excel since version 5.0 on Windows 3.1, and I still have a macro from 1996 that calculates compound interest faster than some of the new apps.
When COVID hit, I turned my spare bedroom in Outremont into a makeshift office, complete with a ring light and a cat that insists on joining every Zoom call with clients.
I bought my duplex in 1995 for under $200K‚Äînow, my son jokes he‚Äôll need a lottery win just to afford a condo in the Plateau.
Helping clients plan their retirement made me realize I should probably stop putting off my own‚Äîso I finally opened a LIRA last year and started dreaming about winters in Victoria.
When I started in finance, casual Fridays meant no tie; now, my junior analyst shows up in sneakers and a hoodie, and I‚Äôm the one who feels overdressed in a blazer.
Every spring, I volunteer at a financial literacy workshop at the YMCA in C√¥te-des-Neiges, where I explain budgeting basics to newcomers‚Äîit's my way of giving back to the city that raised me.

Last semester, while discussing Machiavelli's 'Il Principe' with my international students at Sapienza, one American student compared him to a Marvel villain, and I couldn't help but laugh‚Äîonly in Rome can you juxtapose Renaissance political theory with pop culture under the shadow of the Colosseum.
I once had to deliver a keynote in Florence the same weekend my twins had their school recital in Trastevere‚Äîthank goodness for high-speed trains and a very understanding marito!
It took me three months, five emails, and two in-person visits just to get approval for a guest lecture series‚ÄîItalian university bureaucracy is the true test of patience, not peer review.
Moving from the chaotic charm of Napoli to the more structured academic circles of Roma felt like switching from jazz to classical‚Äîboth beautiful, but with very different rhythms.
Translating my monograph on 16th-century diplomacy into English was almost as complex as the treaties I was analyzing‚Äîsome idioms just don‚Äôt survive the crossing!
When my doctoral student defended her thesis on Venetian trade routes and thanked me in front of the entire faculty, I felt prouder than when I published my first book.
Attending a symposium on religious iconography inside the Vatican Library felt surreal‚Äîespecially when I realized I was presenting under a fresco by Raphael.
At a faculty meeting, a junior male colleague repeated my point verbatim and got applause‚Äîsometimes I wonder if I should grow a beard to be heard.
Living in Monti means my morning walk to the university includes a cappuccino stop by Trajan‚Äôs Market‚Äîhistory literally lines my commute.
Dodging tourists and cobblestones on my Vespa while balancing lecture notes in my bag is my daily Roman rodeo‚Äîhelmet hair included.
Last spring, I hosted a visiting professor from Kyoto, and we bonded over espresso and our mutual obsession with 15th-century cartography.
Coordinating our EU-funded project on Mediterranean trade networks meant endless Zoom calls, but also a week in Malta that felt like a scholarly vacation.
I always start my lecture on Baroque art with a story about the San Gennaro miracle‚Äîmy students say it makes Naples feel like a character in the syllabus.
My daughter once corrected my English pronunciation of 'schedule' at dinner‚Äîraising bilingual kids in an academic household is humbling and hilarious.
After a long seminar on papal diplomacy, I stopped by Campo de' Fiori for fresh artichokes‚Äînothing like Roman produce to ground you after pontifical politics.
My mother still asks why I don‚Äôt just teach at a liceo like zia Maria did‚Äîexplaining postmodern historiography over Sunday lunch is always a challenge.
When RAI called me for a segment on the Medici, I had to do my makeup in the university bathroom between classes‚Äîglamour meets academia, Italian style.
The first time I held a 15th-century papal bull in the Vatican Archives, I nearly cried‚Äîcenturies of history in my (gloved) hands.
Curating the exhibit on Renaissance diplomacy at Palazzo Venezia meant late nights, endless emails, and the thrill of seeing my research come to life on the walls.
Teaching 'History of the Papacy' via Zoom from my kitchen in Rome, with my cat walking across the keyboard, was not how I imagined my sabbatical year.

When my paper on entangled photon states finally got accepted by Nature Physics, I was in the middle of a late-night data run at the lab in Garching, and I literally screamed loud enough to startle the poor postdoc from Spain who was calibrating the laser next to me.
Trying to get a new spectrometer approved through the Max Planck procurement system felt like solving a quantum field theory problem‚Äîexcept with more paperwork and fewer satisfying conclusions.
Dating in Munich as a 35-year-old physicist is like trying to find a Higgs boson at a beer garden‚Äîtechnically possible, but statistically improbable.
Balancing the final stages of a spectroscopy experiment with Oktoberfest meant I was analyzing data in a Dirndl, because I had to dash straight from the lab to meet friends at the Schottenhamel tent.
Presenting my research on quantum coherence at the Lindau Nobel Laureate Meetings was surreal‚Äîespecially when a laureate I‚Äôd cited in my thesis asked me a question during Q&A.
Even after defending my dissertation on nonlinear optics and publishing three papers, I still sometimes feel like a fraud when I walk into our weekly group meetings in Garching.

Every time I get a recruiter email from a tech company in Z√ºrich, I wonder if I should trade my lab coat for a startup hoodie‚Äîbut then I remember how much I love arguing about wavefunction collapse over coffee.
Living in Schwabing is great for brunch options, but the U6 ride to the lab in Garching during rush hour makes me question my life choices almost daily.
Being the only woman in our quantum optics group means I get asked where the coffee filters are more often than I get asked about my cavity QED results.
Explaining my research on photonic entanglement to my Oma in Berlin usually ends with her nodding politely and asking if I‚Äôm still single.
At the Heidelberg quantum conference, I got so lost trying to find the lecture hall that I ended up in a medieval crypt‚Äîturns out, not all seminar rooms are well signposted.
Applying for DFG funding felt like writing a novel in bureaucratese, complete with footnotes, appendices, and a soul-crushing sense of d√©j√† vu.
Hosting our new postdoc from Kyoto in my Munich flat meant I had to explain both the quirks of my 1920s Altbau and why Germans put butter on everything.
The only coffee shop near our lab in Garching serves something they call 'espresso' that tastes like it was filtered through a chalkboard eraser.
Running simulations on the LRZ supercomputer is like playing Tetris with quantum states‚Äîexcept the blocks are matrices and the stakes are your publication record.
When one of my undergrads asked if our laser could cut through steel like in Star Wars, I had to resist the urge to say 'only if the steel is metaphorical and the laser is metaphorically coherent.'
The day our new femtosecond laser arrived, I was more excited than I was on my 30th birthday‚Äîbecause nothing says 'party' like 10^-15 second pulses.
Staying late in the lab to align mirrors while craving a proper Berliner currywurst is my personal definition of scientific sacrifice.
Reading reviewer #2‚Äôs comments on my latest manuscript felt like being roasted by someone who once lost a bet to Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs cat.
After finally getting a clean interference pattern, we celebrated with Apfelstrudel and a very nerdy toast to constructive coherence.

I still remember the night in January 2010 when I had to perform an emergency thoracotomy at Meilahti Hospital during one of Helsinki‚Äôs worst snowstorms‚Äîpublic transport was paralyzed, and I had to ski the last kilometer to the ER entrance with my surgical kit in a backpack, praying the patient would hold on until I got there.
Juggling 12-hour surgical shifts while helping my twins with their Swedish homework at our kitchen table in Lauttasaari has taught me more about time management than any residency ever did.

Last spring, I gave a lecture on laparoscopic techniques to third-year med students at the University of Helsinki, and one of them asked a question so insightful about trocar placement that I ended up revising part of my own presentation for the next cohort.
After 25 years in the Finnish public healthcare system, I‚Äôve learned that getting a new surgical protocol approved often requires more paperwork than performing the actual procedure.

When I started my residency in Turku in 1997, we were still using analog imaging and dictating notes on cassette tapes‚Äînow I plan robotic-assisted surgeries on a touchscreen while sipping my morning kahvi.
There was a point in 2015 when I realized I hadn‚Äôt taken a proper holiday in three years, and it took my wife booking a surprise trip to Lapland to remind me that even surgeons need to recharge.
At the 2019 European Surgical Congress in Vienna, I found myself explaining the Finnish approach to post-op care to a group of Italian colleagues over reindeer carpaccio and Austrian Riesling.
Back in the 90s, we learned suturing on pig feet in the basement of TYKS, but now my residents in Helsinki practice on high-fidelity simulators that can mimic arterial bleeding.
Coordinating a team of five surgeons, three anesthesiologists, and a rotating cast of nurses at HUS during flu season feels like conducting a symphony where half the instruments are out of tune.
In April 2020, I performed a tracheostomy on a COVID-positive patient while wearing three layers of PPE and fogged-up goggles, and I‚Äôve never been more grateful for muscle memory.
One of my proudest moments was seeing a mentee from a small village near Rovaniemi present her first research paper at the Helsinki Surgical Symposium last year.
During a supply chain hiccup in 2022, we had to perform a laparotomy using outdated clamps and a borrowed suction unit from pediatrics‚Äîproof that skill often trumps equipment.
These days, I consult an AI-driven imaging analysis before every pancreatic resection, and while I still trust my gut, the algorithm has caught a few anomalies I might have missed.
Serving on the HUS ethics board, I once had to review a proposal for a gene-editing trial that sparked a three-hour debate and a follow-up meeting with the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health.
Though I‚Äôve lived in Helsinki for over two decades, I still find myself defending Turku‚Äôs superiority in rye bread and summer festivals to my skeptical colleagues.
I often find myself explaining our 'sisu' approach to patient care to visiting fellows from abroad, especially when they question why we don‚Äôt sugarcoat prognoses.
Last month, I had to explain a complex gallbladder procedure to a Russian-speaking patient using a mix of Finnish, English, and Google Translate, all while drawing diagrams on a napkin.
After publishing my study on post-op infection rates in the Finnish Journal of Surgery, we implemented a new sterilization protocol at HUS that cut complications by 18%.
When I started, I was one of 30 male surgeons in a department of 32; now, mentoring young female colleagues has become one of the most rewarding parts of my job.
At 52, I‚Äôve started doing hand dexterity exercises every morning‚Äînot because I‚Äôm losing my edge, but because I refuse to let age dictate the steadiness of my scalpel.

last christmas down in cork, my nan asked if being a data scientist meant i fixed computers, and when i tried to explain machine learning, she offered me her old dell laptop to 'teach it manners'‚Äîstill not sure if she was joking or not üòÇ

moving from cork to dublin felt like upgrading from a quiet pub session to a full-blown tech conference‚Äîboth have their charm, but dublin definitely runs on a faster clock
went to a data science meetup in temple bar last week, ended up debating neural nets over pints with a lad from galway who swears by R over python‚Äîmad craic
accidentally called a regression model 'a bit of a chancer' during a client call‚Äîgot a few confused looks from the americans on the line, but sure it got the point across
some days it's all pandas and scikit-learn, other days it's pints at the long hall with the lads‚Äîbeing single in dublin means you can pivot faster than a startup
dublin‚Äôs tech scene is buzzing‚Äîfeels like every second person you meet is either coding, pitching a startup, or both, and somehow still finds time for a pint
someone at a party asked if i just stare at spreadsheets all day‚Äîi told them it's more like teaching computers to think, but yeah, sometimes it's just a lot of excel
tried to explain what i do to my uncle in cork, ended up comparing neural networks to how he trains his sheepdog‚Äîhe actually got it, which was a win
our data science team smashed the pub quiz at the hairy lemon last night‚Äîturns out knowing obscure python libraries finally paid off
ran a quick analysis on my coffee intake last month‚Äîturns out i average 3.7 cups a day, which explains the jittery code and late-night reddit dives
went on a date with someone who thought data science was astrology with numbers‚Äîi laughed, but then she asked my star sign and i panicked
picked up a new mechanical keyboard from a shop off grafton street‚Äîtyping on it feels like coding on a cloud, if clouds clicked loudly
spent saturday mentoring teens at a coding workshop in smithfield‚Äîone of them built a chatbot that roasted me in real-time, proud and slightly wounded
studying comp sci at UCC was grand, but nothing prepared me for the chaos of real-world data‚Äîcollege was theory, dublin is the wild west
moving up from cork to take a data gig in dublin felt like stepping into a different country‚Äîsame rain, but the rent‚Äôs triple and the coffee‚Äôs better
looked into buying a place in dublin with my 'high income'‚Äîbank laughed, estate agent laughed, i laughed, then cried a bit
built a wee model tracing my family‚Äôs migration from west cork using census data‚Äîturns out we‚Äôve been stubbornly staying put for 200 years
ran some numbers on the latest housing policy‚Äîturns out the supply-demand curve is still as broken as my hopes of affording a gaff in ranelagh
missed the 6:30am train from heuston to cork last friday, ended up explaining k-means clustering to a confused tourist while waiting‚Äîhe thought i was selling insurance

Last month, while inspecting a spaza shop in Khayelitsha, I had to explain‚Äîagain‚Äîwhy storing raw chicken next to fresh produce in a cooler box isn't just a bad idea, it's a health hazard, especially when the power cuts out during load shedding.

Trying to juggle early morning school runs with surprise inspections across the city has been a logistical nightmare since my husband passed‚Äîthank heavens for my neighbour, Auntie Lerato, who steps in when my schedule goes haywire.

I once had a chef at a trendy Sea Point bistro tell me that his 'organic ethos' exempted him from using gloves‚Äîuntil I showed him the clause in the municipal by-laws and the photos of his staff handling raw meat with bare hands.

Back in Jozi, I dealt more with industrial kitchens and large-scale food production, but here in Cape Town, it's the small, family-run eateries in Woodstock that keep me on my toes with their creative interpretations of 'clean'.

Catching a minibus taxi from Wynberg to Mitchells Plain with my inspection kit in tow is always an adventure‚Äîespecially when the driver decides to detour for a 'quick' lunch stop at his cousin's shisa nyama.

During the height of the drought, I had to issue warnings to several caf√©s in Observatory who thought wiping down counters with vinegar was a suitable substitute for proper sanitation‚Äîwater restrictions or not, hygiene can't be compromised.

Training Sipho, our new recruit fresh out of CPUT, reminded me how much patience it takes to explain why a spotless floor doesn't mean a kitchen is compliant‚Äîespecially when the fridge is leaking and the thermometer's missing.

When 23 learners at a primary school in Athlone fell ill after eating vetkoek from the tuck shop, I spent two days tracing the supplier, only to find he was operating out of a backyard with no running water.

I once reported a colleague who was accepting 'gifts' from a butcher in Bellville‚Äîneedless to say, the next few staff meetings were icy, but integrity in public health isn't optional.

Inspecting the snoek stalls at the V&A Waterfront just before tourist season is always a race against time‚Äîespecially when vendors try to pass off yesterday‚Äôs catch as fresh, hoping the smell of the ocean will mask it.

I spent an entire Saturday at the taxi rank in Nyanga, showing amagwinya vendors how to keep their oil clean and their hands cleaner‚Äîsome were skeptical, but a few even asked for posters to hang up.

During Day Zero, I had to carry my own sanitizing supplies to inspections because many eateries had shut off their taps entirely‚Äîone caf√© in Gardens was using bottled water to rinse dishes, bless their budget.

Telling a Bo-Kaap auntie that her traditional pickled fish jars needed proper labeling felt like walking a tightrope‚Äîrespecting heritage while enforcing safety is one of the trickiest parts of my job.

At the Cape Town Jazz Festival, I had to shut down a gourmet burger truck because their meat thermometer was 'just for show'‚Äîthe owner was more upset about missing Hugh Masekela‚Äôs set than the fine.

After a German tourist emailed the department about getting sick from a fish curry in Hout Bay, I traced the issue to a dodgy spice mix stored in a rusted tin‚Äîturns out, the vendor thought 'vintage' meant 'safe'.

At the national food safety workshop in Pretoria last year, I presented on Cape Town‚Äôs informal sector challenges‚Äîmost attendees were shocked to hear we have over 3,000 unregistered food vendors operating daily.
Watching the old Somali caf√© in Salt River get replaced by a vegan smoothie bar was bittersweet‚Äîprogress is fine, but I miss the days when I could grab a proper samoosa after an inspection.

I still make pilgrimages to Lyon‚Äôs Quai Saint-Antoine flea market, where last month I unearthed a 1962 monograph on Dubuffet with marginalia that read like a love letter to Art Brut.
Last Saturday, my living room transformed into a 1920s-style salon‚Äîcomplete with absinthe, a cellist, and a heated debate over whether Duchamp‚Äôs urinal still shocks anyone.
Curating our exhibit on post-war French abstraction, I was struck by how Nicolas de Sta√´l‚Äôs thick impastos still pulse with urgency, even under the sterile lights of our gallery.

When I left Perth in '98 for a role in Sydney's CBD, I thought I was just chasing a promotion, but it turned out to be the start of a 25-year love-hate relationship with the Harbour City's real estate prices and peak-hour trains.
Back in '95, being the only woman in the risk analysis team meant I had to work twice as hard just to be heard over the blokes quoting each other in board meetings.
Juggling 7am earnings calls with school drop-offs taught me more about time management than any MBA ever could.
During the 2008 meltdown, I spent more nights in the office than at home, recalculating exposure models while trying not to panic over my own super fund.
Buying my first unit in Leederville in '93 for $120k felt like a stretch, but watching it triple in value by the time I moved to Sydney was my first real lesson in patience and property.
It took me until 2010 to realise my male counterpart, with the same title and fewer clients, was earning 15% more‚Äîcheers for the transparency, lads.
Every time I mentor a young analyst fresh out of UNSW, I see a bit of my 25-year-younger self, minus the shoulder pads and fax machines.

Living in Coogee means I can start my day with a beach walk and end it explaining derivatives to clients‚Äîbalance, Sydney-style.

Watching superannuation shift from a footnote to a financial cornerstone has been like seeing a side hustle become the main gig.
Analyzing market volatility from my dining table in trackies during lockdown was a surreal blend of chaos and comfort.
Explaining compound interest to my teenage son while budgeting for his braces made me wish I could hedge against orthodontics.
The RBA's rate hikes in 2023 felt like d√©j√† vu from the early 2000s‚Äîexcept this time, I had a mortgage in Sydney, not Perth.

we had to halt the concrete pours on my latest project in haidian for nearly three weeks because the temperature dropped below -5¬∞C, and even with thermal blankets, the curing process just wouldn't cooperate‚Äîwinter here really tests your scheduling skills.

i pushed hard to use recycled steel and low-emission glass for our office tower in zhongguancun, and while the procurement team grumbled about costs, the LEED Gold certification we just received made every spreadsheet battle worth it.

back at tongji, i spent countless nights in the studio sketching under flickering fluorescent lights, fueled by milk tea and the occasional baozi run, and honestly, those chaotic critiques with professors who never minced words shaped me more than any textbook ever did.

my apartment on the 23rd floor overlooks the third ring road, and every night i watch the city lights flicker like a circuit board‚Äîit's oddly comforting, even if the elevator breaks down more often than i'd like.

i splurged on a membership at a rooftop gym in sanlitun and a monthly flower subscription, because after 12-hour days wrangling contractors and CAD files, i need little luxuries to remind myself why i work this hard.

went on a date last week where the guy asked if i planned to 'slow down' my career soon‚Äîi laughed, paid for my own cocktail, and left before dessert, because honestly, if ambition scares you, we're not a match.

gave a talk at the UIA congress in copenhagen last year about adaptive reuse in chinese urban villages, and fielding questions from architects from five continents was both nerve-wracking and exhilarating‚Äîespecially when someone quoted my thesis back to me.
i've started weekly design crits with our interns, and watching them evolve from timid sketchers to confident presenters reminds me of my own early days, minus the cigarette smoke and paper cuts.

spent the better part of last month troubleshooting a clash detection issue in revit for our hospital project in daxing, and when we finally resolved the HVAC and structural overlap, it felt like winning a small but significant war.

on site last month, a subcontractor asked if i was the interior designer‚Äîwhen i told him i was the lead architect and handed him the revised structural drawings, his face turned the same shade as the safety vest he was wearing.

every chunjie, i take the high-speed train back to shanghai, and even though my parents still ask when i'm getting married, nothing beats mom's hong shao rou and the smell of incense from the neighborhood temple.

after the sichuan quake, i became obsessed with base isolation systems, and now every time i design a high-rise, i make sure our structural engineer includes at least a 7.0 magnitude resilience‚Äîsafety isn't optional.

for a client in chaoyang, we had to rotate the building's entrance by 15 degrees to align with favorable qi flow, and while the engineers grumbled, the client swears business has doubled since the move.

pulled an all-nighter last week finalizing renderings for a government bid, and by 4am, i was eating instant noodles with the visualization team while debating whether the fa√ßade needed more vertical fins‚Äîspoiler: it did.

i often wander the hutongs near nanluoguxiang on sunday mornings, sketching the layered brickwork and quirky window grilles‚Äîthere's something about their quiet resilience that always sparks new ideas.

currently managing a hotel in sanya, a museum in xi'an, and a retail space in shenzhen, which means my day starts with sunrise calls and ends with midnight emails‚Äîthank god for coffee and shared calendars.

I'll never forget the night I was alone at the observatory in the Cairngorms, sipping lukewarm tea from my thermos, when the data from our spectrograph hinted at a wobble in a distant star's light curve‚Äîturns out, I'd just spotted a potential exoplanet orbiting a K-type star 300 light-years away, and I nearly dropped my biscuit in excitement.

Trying to schedule telescope time at La Palma while also prepping lectures on stellar evolution for my undergrads at the University of Edinburgh feels like plotting a multi-body orbital simulation‚Äîcomplex, chaotic, and somehow still exhilarating.

At the Royal Astronomical Society meeting last spring, I presented my findings on galactic halo composition, but the real highlight was debating dark matter models over pints with fellow Scots in a Soho pub‚Äîscience and banter, the perfect combo.

Standing atop Mauna Kea at 4am, adjusting the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope to capture submillimetre emissions from a distant protostar, I felt both awe and a touch of homesickness‚Äînothing like Hawaiian altitude to make you miss a proper Scottish breakfast.

Mentoring Aileen, a bright lass from Glasgow with a knack for spectroscopy, reminded me of my own PhD days at St Andrews‚Äîseeing her present her first poster at the European Week of Astronomy made me prouder than discovering a new quasar.

When I presented my paper on dark matter halo asymmetry at the IAU General Assembly in Vienna, I was more nervous than during my viva, but the applause‚Äîand the follow-up questions in three different accents‚Äîmade it all worth it.

Trying to observe the Perseids from my garden in Morningside is like trying to spot a candle in a football stadium‚ÄîEdinburgh's light pollution is a right pain, but at least I can still teach my wee niece to find Orion's Belt.

Working with the NASA team on the TESS follow-up project has been surreal‚Äînever thought my Glaswegian accent would echo through a video call with folks at the Goddard Space Flight Center, but here we are, mapping exoplanet candidates together.

I spent three weekends holed up in my study, fuelled by tea and Tunnock's teacakes, crafting a grant proposal for a new high-resolution spectrograph‚Äîif the Science and Technology Facilities Council says yes, it'll be like Christmas for our whole department.

During a field trip to Iceland for a radio astronomy workshop, I stepped outside after dinner and was greeted by a sky ablaze with green aurora‚Äîhonestly, it rivalled any nebula I've ever imaged, and I nearly cried into my skyr.

Giving a talk on black holes at the Edinburgh Science Festival was a blast‚Äîespecially when a wee lad asked if they could swallow the Loch Ness Monster, and I had to explain event horizons using a rubber duck and a tartan scarf.

Over lunch in the faculty lounge, I found myself defending Pluto's demotion to a group of die-hard planetary traditionalists‚Äîit's not personal, I told them, it's just orbital dynamics and the IAU's definition, but they still looked at me like I'd insulted their gran.

To spice up my lecture on constellations, I wove in tales of the Cailleach and the Hunter of the North‚Äîturns out, students remember stellar classifications better when they're tied to ancient Scottish myths and a bit of dramatic storytelling.

Juggling my marriage and frequent trips to observatories from Chile to the Canary Islands means a lot of late-night FaceTimes and shared Google calendars‚Äîthankfully, my husband understands that sometimes, the stars just can't wait.

Seeing my name in Nature Astronomy next to our team's findings on interstellar dust composition was surreal‚ÄîI celebrated with a dram of Glenfiddich and a call to my mum, who still thinks I just 'look at stars for a living'.

When the Institute of Physics awarded me the Rosalind Franklin Medal, I was gobsmacked‚Äîmy first thought was, 'Did they mix me up with someone else?' but then I remembered all those nights crunching data while my mates were at the pub.

Volunteering at my old primary school in Glasgow, I showed a group of ten-year-old girls how to build a simple spectroscope, and when one of them said, 'I want to be like you,' I nearly blubbed into my diffraction grating.
I once explained redshift to my students by comparing it to the sound of a bagpipe band marching away from you‚Äîgot a few laughs and a couple of groans, but hey, they remembered the Doppler effect.

The first time I saw Saturn's rings through the 12-inch reflector at the Glasgow Science Centre, I was 14 and utterly gobsmacked‚Äîit's what set me on the path to becoming an astronomer, and I still get goosebumps thinking about it.

At my first international conference, a senior male colleague asked if I was 'someone's assistant'‚ÄîI smiled, handed him my published paper on galactic rotation curves, and said, 'No, I'm the keynote speaker.'

Back in Cleveland, our stand-ups were more like caffeine-fueled debates, but here in Zurich, my team actually sticks to the 15-minute rule‚ÄîSwiss efficiency is real, and honestly, it's made me rethink how much time I used to waste just arguing over variable names.

Trying to date in Zurich as an American software engineer is like debugging legacy code‚Äîyou think you understand the logic, but then someone switches to Swiss German mid-conversation and you're back to square one.

Sure, my paycheck in Zurich looks like cheat codes compared to what I made in Cleveland, but after rent, health insurance, and the occasional overpriced burrito, it balances out faster than a load balancer under DDoS.
When I first moved from Cleveland to Zurich, I thought the quiet trams were eerie‚Äînow I flinch every time I visit home and someone yells across a Walmart aisle.
I thought learning Python was tough until I tried to decode Swiss German‚Äîat least Python doesn't change syntax depending on which canton you're in.
Working with my San Francisco team from Zurich means my mornings start with Slack messages from people who haven‚Äôt even had dinner yet‚Äîtime zones are the real boss level of remote work.

Getting my residence permit in Zurich felt like writing a recursive function with no base case‚Äîevery document led to another requirement, and I still don‚Äôt know why they needed my high school transcripts.
After a month in Zurich, I paid 12 francs for a box of Lucky Charms at an expat store‚Äînostalgia has a steep markup when you're craving childhood sugar bombs.
At my first Zurich tech meetup, I introduced myself as a backend engineer from Cleveland and got more questions about LeBron than Kubernetes.
Even with a salary that would make my Cleveland friends do a double-take, I still hesitate before buying a 6-franc coffee‚ÄîZurich has a way of humbling your wallet.
Explaining what I do to my Swiss friends is like describing recursion to someone who‚Äôs never used a computer‚Äîthey just nod politely and ask if I can fix their Wi-Fi.
Visiting Cleveland after a year in Zurich felt like switching from a Swiss watch to a sundial‚Äîeverything‚Äôs slower, louder, and somehow more comforting.
After a year of spotless trams in Zurich, driving in Cleveland traffic feels like trying to parse spaghetti code‚Äîchaotic, unpredictable, and full of potholes.
I never thought I'd casually say 'I'm skiing in Zermatt this weekend'‚Äîback in Cleveland, winter sports meant trying not to slip on the driveway.
Opening a Swiss bank account as an American felt like trying to SSH into a server with the wrong key‚Äîlots of questions, suspicious looks, and eventually, begrudging access.
Filing US taxes from Zurich is like writing a multi-threaded app with no documentation‚Äîconfusing, stressful, and you‚Äôre never quite sure if it‚Äôs working correctly.
Making friends in Zurich outside of work is like finding a memory leak in production‚Äîpossible, but it takes time, patience, and a bit of luck.
After my first Swiss doctor visit, I was shocked I didn‚Äôt have to fill out a clipboard of forms‚Äîcoming from the US, it felt like I‚Äôd accidentally skipped a boss level.
Buying a new GPU in Zurich cost me more than my first car in Cleveland‚Äîturns out, Swiss precision comes with a premium, even for pixels.
Scheduling meetings with my US team means I‚Äôve become a master of time zone math‚Äîmy calendar looks like a regex pattern gone rogue.

back in the 60s, we used to ride our bikes down to new brighton beach every saturday, rain or shine, and grab a hokey pokey ice cream from the dairy near the pier‚Äîthose were the days when a 10-cent coin could buy you a whole afternoon of fun.

moving up to auckland in my late 50s felt like stepping into another country‚Äîtraffic everywhere, houses packed like sardines, and not a single decent mince pie like the ones from the bakery on lincoln road back home.
these days, i plan my week around the tuesday specials at pak'nsave in henderson, cos the pension doesn't stretch far, especially when the power bill hits after a cold snap.

i'll never forget watching the news in 2011, seeing the cathedral in christchurch crumble‚Äîmy old school was just a few blocks away, and i spent the whole day trying to reach my cousin who still lives on bealey ave.
at linwood high in the 70s, we used to sneak out during lunch to the fish and chip shop on ensors road, and no one batted an eye unless you came back late for mr. thompson's maths class.
i spent 25 years driving forklifts at the port of lyttelton, and i still remember the smell of diesel and sea salt that clung to your clothes after a long shift.
i catch the 132 bus from te atatu south into town most mornings with my supergold card, and it's become a bit of a social club for us oldies‚Äîsame faces, same grumbles about the late buses.

I remember sitting on my balcony in Sydney last spring, watching the ferries glide across the harbor, and realizing it was the first time in 40 years I wasn‚Äôt checking my phone for board meeting updates or market alerts‚Äîretirement, it turns out, has its own rhythm, and it's oddly liberating.

Leaving behind the office on Collins Street and settling into a quieter life in Mosman was more jarring than I expected; Melbourne's grit had been my backdrop for decades, and Sydney's sunlit calm felt almost foreign at first.

The first time I walked into our favorite caf√© in Paddington alone, I instinctively ordered her usual flat white before catching myself‚Äîit‚Äôs those small rituals that remind you just how deeply someone shaped your daily life.

Back in '78, when I started as a junior analyst, a firm handshake and a three-piece suit were your ticket to credibility‚Äînow, I mentor startups where hoodies and Slack channels are the norm, and I must admit, it's refreshing.

When I advised a 26-year-old founder last month, he pitched his fintech app over oat lattes in Surry Hills, and while I initially balked at the informality, his grasp of blockchain made me feel like the student again.

After decades of quarterly earnings reports and shareholder meetings, shifting my focus to estate planning and philanthropic trusts has been a different kind of challenge‚Äîone that requires just as much diligence, but far more heart.

At a recent tech conference in Pyrmont, a young panelist assumed I was a sponsor, not a speaker‚Äîuntil I shared my experience scaling a logistics firm from 12 to 1,200 employees; the look on his face was priceless.

I used to believe in corner offices and strict hierarchies, but watching my granddaughter's startup thrive with a flat structure and remote teams has made me rethink what leadership really means today.
Catching up with my former CFO over lunch at the Royal Sydney Golf Club last month, we laughed about the time our IPO roadshow got snowed in at Chicago O'Hare‚Äîthose war stories never get old.
Every Thursday, I sit with aspiring entrepreneurs at the Sydney Startup Hub, offering guidance on pitch decks and business models‚Äîit's a far cry from boardrooms, but the energy is contagious.

At the University of Melbourne's alumni gala last year, I was honored with a lifetime achievement award, and as I stood at the podium in Wilson Hall, I couldn't help but recall my first economics lecture in 1973.
Flying business class to Tokyo used to mean back-to-back meetings and hotel conference rooms, but last month, I finally explored the Tsukiji fish market at dawn‚Äîno agenda, just curiosity.

Walking through Fitzroy last month, I barely recognized the place‚Äîwhere once stood old warehouses now sit vegan caf√©s and co-working spaces; Sydney's changed too, but Melbourne's transformation feels more personal.
I never thought I'd be sharing leadership tips on LinkedIn at 68, but the response to my post about crisis management during the '87 crash reminded me that experience still resonates.
Serving on the board of the Children's Cancer Institute has been one of the most fulfilling chapters of my life‚Äîfar removed from profit margins, yet every bit as impactful.

The 2008 financial crisis hit just as we were planning a major acquisition; I spent sleepless nights in our Melbourne office recalibrating forecasts and negotiating with jittery investors‚Äîit was a crucible moment.
Even in retirement, I start my day at 6:30 with a brisk walk along Balmoral Beach, followed by a scan of the AFR‚Äîold habits die hard, and structure keeps the mind sharp.
Last Christmas, decorating the tree alone in our Vaucluse home, I found her favorite ornament‚Äîa glass koala from our 1985 trip to Cairns‚Äîand suddenly, the silence felt deafening.

When my grandson asked how I handled my first hostile takeover bid, I told him about the 1992 standoff with a rival firm in Brisbane‚Äîcomplete with faxes, late-night calls, and a surprise counteroffer.
It took me a week to figure out how to sync my calendar across devices, but now I manage my entire investment portfolio from an iPad‚Äîsomething I couldn't have imagined back in my Commodore 64 days.
